_decoded_content.title: Docs: Document `env` usage in Environments
_decoded_content.description: The [Environment page in the docs](https://docs.meltano.com/concepts/environments) is not currently doing a great work at explaining the effects of using the `env` mapping in an Environment.

Simplify and rebuild 'Installation' docs page
Docs: Add Meltano project showcase to docs
_decoded_content.description: It would be great to have a list of production Meltano projects that folks could reference and learn from. https://meltano.slack.com/archives/C01UTUSP34M/p1646860173296319?thread_ts=1646854828.460529&cid=C01UTUSP34M

_decoded_content.title: Rearrange docs sidebar and fix footer links
_decoded_content.description:
In the sidebar, I suggest moving the “Reference” section before “Contribute”, so that all the stuff that targets users comes before that which targets contributors. “Guide” may also make more sense before “Concepts”, so that someone isn't overwhelmed with all the new stuff to learn and is instead guided through it.

These docs look outdated to me and I think can be removed:
- https://docs.meltano.com/tutorials/install-on-aws
- https://docs.meltano.com/tutorials/postgres-with-postgres
- https://docs.meltano.com/reference/architecture
- https://docs.meltano.com/reference/role-based-access-control

I also just noticed that the GitLab button in the top right links to the handbook repo, not docs, and the MeltanoLabs and Meltano Hub links in the footer link to unrelated pages.

_decoded_content.title: contributor-guide link broken
_decoded_content.description: https://docs.meltano.com/ -> Contribute! link that points to https://docs.meltano.com/the-project/contributor-guide is broken

_decoded_content.title: Create a documentation strategy for Meltano
_decoded_content.description:
_(Excluding SDK topics here, but same principals should apply.)_

Starting here a discussion to come up with a robust documentation strategy.

Would love if this can be inspired by and informed by some of the great thought leadership at https://www.writethedocs.org/, especially:

- https://diataxis.fr/ - The Diataxis Framework
- https://www.writethedocs.org/guide/
- https://www.writethedocs.org/guide/writing/docs-principles/
- https://docs-guide.readthedocs.io/en/latest/doctypes/
- https://documentation.divio.com/

Would be very good if we can start with a framing, something along the lines of:

1. What types of documentation are we creating and who is the audience for each?
2. What is the lifecycle of each type of documentation?
   1. How is it added and by whom?
   1. How is it maintained and by whom?
   1. Is automation involved?

Cc @afolson, @Emily, @tayloramurphy, @edgarrmondragon, @pandemicsyn 

## Proposed Docs "Types":

1. Tutorials - _Learning-oriented_
1. Topical Guides
   1. How-To Guides - _Problem-oriented_
   2. Explanation - _Understanding-oriented_
1. Reference - _Information-oriented_
   1. Reference Docs (for Users)
      1. CLI reference
      1. Yaml file reference
      1. REST API reference
   1. Contributor Reference Docs (also for Core Team)
      * Repo structure
      * Module-level docs
      * Etc. (https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/issues/3285#note_855733400 and https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/issues/3208)

_decoded_content.title: Review all docs links in code to ensure they point to docs.meltano.com
Allow query url params on doc search site
_decoded_content.description:
If we updated the docs search page (https://docs.meltano.com/search) to accept an optional query param for populating/submitting the initial search (e.g. https://docs.meltano.com/search?term=settings) you could use it as a search engine shortcut with various browsers, extensions, and we could submit `!meltano` (or `!melty`) as a !bang short cut on DuckDuckGo. 

For those unfamiliar, !bang search shortcuts are aliases that let you do site-specific searches so `!melty settings` would use  `https://docs.meltano.com/search?term=settings`

_decoded_content.title: Docs: Make sidebar collapsible for easier readbility
_decoded_content.description: I like what Dagster is doing with their docs https://docs.dagster.io/getting-started Collapsing the sidebar would make it easier to understand the information hierarchy and not overwhelm the user.

_decoded_content.title: Docs: update search to be "inline" and not require leaving the page
Docs: Add a keyboard shortcut to focus on search bar
Reference Implementations
_decoded_content.description:
I'm not sure where the SDK docs are managed but there are some other good code samples and reference implementations that can get added. Right now the list is limited https://sdk.meltano.com/en/latest/code_samples.html. 

Also linking to the [academy repo](https://gitlab.com/meltano/academy/-/blob/main/labs/build_your_own_tap.md) and MeltanoLabs might be good resources too.

_decoded_content.title: Remove other references to editable installs not being supported with Poetry
_decoded_content.description:
When we documented support for [PEP 660 in `poetry-core` allowing editable installations for SDK-based packages](https://gitlab.com/meltano/sdk/-/merge_requests/231), we failed to remove a few references to the old shell script and editable installations not being supported. 

- https://sdk.meltano.com/en/latest/cli_commands.html#meltano
- https://sdk.meltano.com/en/latest/python_tips.html#if-you-already-know-about-virtual-environments

_decoded_content.title: Document that `get_starting_timestamp` requires setting a non-null replication_key
_decoded_content.description:
From slack thread: https://meltano.slack.com/archives/C01TCRBBJD7/p1643646009947879

`Stream.get_starting_timestamp(context)` returns `None` if `Stream.replication_key` is not set for the stream. Documentation for [`get_starting_timestamp(context)`](https://sdk.meltano.com/en/latest/classes/singer_sdk.Stream.html#singer_sdk.Stream.get_starting_timestamp) should indicate that requirement.

_decoded_content.title: Improve documentation around what a namespace is and does
_decoded_content.description:
Reading through the documentation, we don't do a good job of explaining what `namespace` does or means. There's no mental model we're trying to build for the user. When searching for namespace we show the user:

* https://docs.meltano.com/tutorials/postgres-with-postgres#run-meltano-elt
* https://docs.meltano.com/guide/transformation#adding-a-transform-to-your-meltano-project
* https://docs.meltano.com/concepts/project#custom-plugin-definitions
* https://docs.meltano.com/the-project/contributor-guide#plugin-definitions
* https://docs.meltano.com/concepts/plugins#package_name-extra
* https://docs.meltano.com/guide/containerization#gitlab-cicd

But none of those explains what it's doing or why one needs it!

_decoded_content.title: Improve Documentation on Configuring Settings for Custom Plugins
_decoded_content.description:
https://docs.meltano.com/guide/configuration#:~:text=If%20we%E2%80%99re%20dealing%20with%20a%20custom%20plugin%20instead

When configuring a custom plugin, the documentation is not clear that the settings configuration needs to be added for Meltano to pick up Environment Variable values for plugin settings. If settings configuration is not added, then plugin config values need to be added directly to meltano.yml to work.

Documentation should clarify that plugin settings need to be configured for Meltano to pickup environmental variables.

_decoded_content.title: Add additional documention about STATE merge logic
_decoded_content.description:
The following discussion from !2499 should be addressed:

> A couple other things I we should probably address here in the [STATE] docs if we can:
> 
> * Invocations with different `select` filters *do not clobber* each other (I think) - so long as their executions do not overlap each other. This is because the tap treats the state entries as additive, and will send along the state object from the prior run, along with new updates in this run.
> * Invocations run concurrently *do clobber* each other (I think). This is because successful runs replace each other rather than getting merged. So if I run just table A in parallel with just table B, and if table A finishes first, then table B's state will clobber the state of table A and there won't be any bookmarks from the table A execution.

Full thread in !2499 [discussion](https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/merge_requests/2499#note_814445189)
